name: 政治生態學研討
comment: 上課教室：文學院勤10F地理系會議室。
description: Globally there are around 300 million indigenous peoples, consisting of approximately 5000 distinct cultures. They live in every part of the world – ranging from the Arctic Circle to tropical rain forests. It is estimated that indigenous peoples occupy 22% of the world’s surface and live in areas which occupy 80% of the planet’s biodiversity and ecosystems.  The natural environment forms an integral part of many indigenous peoples’ livelihoods, cultures, worldviews, and identities which are essential for their survival. However, many indigenous and local communities are threatened by deforestation, mining, restrictive government policies, and bad consequences of ‘development’. The main aim of this advanced course is to outline the key ideas and theories of political ecology, traditional ecological knowledge (TEK), and local natural resource management, and its underlying principles and approaches. This course allows students to appreciate the ecological, spiritual and socio-cultural values, and holistic nature of TEK, and critically analyze current discourses on natural resource conservation from a political ecology perspective. This course will be suitable for students both in human and physical geography, and for students in sustainability and social sciences. We will focus both on indigenous and local communities in Taiwan, but also in other parts of the world.
goals: Understand and critically discuss theories on political ecology, nature conservation and traditional ecological knowledge systems.
Be familiar with the negative effects of development interventions, land grabbing, economic development and nature conservation on local and indigenous peoples.
Map the different stakeholders and governance regimes involved in nature conservation and rural development from  a political ecology perspective.
Evaluate the sustainability of ‘bottom-up’ nature conservation programs across various geographical contexts.
syllabus:
Week1: Introduction to the Course

Week2: Introduction to Political Ecology

Week3: Indigenous Peoples in the World    

Week4: De-growth and Post-Development Theories

Week5: Traditional Ecological Knowledge: What is TEK and why is it important?      

Week6: Land Grabbing, Mining, and Human Rights

Week7: Critical discourses on Nature Conservation

Week8: Adaptive capacity and Natural Resource Management

Week9: Global Climate Change and Sustainability

Week10: Tropical Forests and Ecotourism

Week11 Fieldtrip to an Indigenous Community in Taiwan

Week12: Political Ecology Issues in Taiwan

Week13: Research Methods in Political Ecology

Week14: Guest Lecture from NGO expert or indigenous activist

Week15: Special topic 1: Disaster governance in Taiwan 

Week16: Special topic 2: Climate Change Adaption and Local Communities in Vietnam

Week17: Final Students’ presentations

Week 18: Final Exam

methodologies.note: This course consists of lecturers which are both theoretical and empirical.
Students are required to lead seminars to practice their presentation skills.
We will visit an Indigenous Community in Taiwan
We will make ample use of media and visual materials during formal lectures.

grading.note:
Write an essay and present it during class – choose a theme related to political ecology (a topic list will be provided) – 20%.
Photo-based essay during the fieldtrip – 20%
Assignment on the guest lecture in the class – 10%
This includes all the readings, discussions, and lectures.
In each class we will have class debates, video assignments, or other forms of class involvement.
Everyone is required to attend the lectures and seminars, unless you have a valid reason not to come.
